Open PowerShell as administrator. 	2. Type: "Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy Bypass"  (without quotes). 	3. Type 'Y' and enter. 	4. Close terminal in vscode.         5. Open new terminal Ctrl+Shift+` or Terminal->New terminal.  Hope this helps.

text: For those receiving the "[ERRNO 2] NO SUCH FILE OR DIRECTORY" that I had when trying to install various scripts and applications...   I had this issue as well. I learned later that the error (which I did not see for some time initially) was only being provided through powershell. I was using Git and CMD prior to that, so make sure you CHECK POWERSHELL to see if you have any errors you hadn't seen otherwise.    Powershell exclusively was providing the error I had, noting that I was not allowing scripts to be ran on my system. You must run powershell AS ADMINISTRATOR then type the following: PS C:\WINDOWS\system32> cd.. PS C:\WINDOWS> cd.. PS C:\>    (This is my, like many others, drive where my programs,python,etc are located)   PS C:\> Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser   (this will bring up a large sum of text noting whether you wish to enable scripts to be ran on the system, with 'A' being yes to all)   Hit the A key.   Check if you get the following after typing the two commands:   PS C:\> Get-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned PS C:\> Get-ExecutionPolicy -LIST          Scope ExecutionPolicy         ----- --------------- MachinePolicy       Undefined UserPolicy       Undefined Process       Undefined CurrentUser    RemoteSigned LocalMachine       Undefined       SRC: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-python/issues/2559 https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_execution_policies?view=powershell-5.1

text: VS Code is great but there are significant changes EVERY MONTH.  So pylint is now included with the Python extension and pylint is not even available any more.  Also, I would avoid using the Conda Python environment with VS Code because Conda also changes quite a bit and is an extra headache to coordinate with VS Code, e.g., Conda activation scripts have changed.  Also, on Windows the VS Code Terminal powershell and cmd  shells use DIFFERENT path variables.  Anaconda Python uses powershell path variables and most other installs use cmd paths (System and User environment variables).  So if you switch between powershell and cmd within the VS Code terminal, it can be very confusing.
